newsitem.title: UK: Russia's Dubinin sees no need for rouble Eurobonds.
newsitem.headline: Russia's Dubinin sees no need for rouble Eurobonds.

text.p: Russia's central bank chairman Sergei Dubinin on Thursday said he did not see the need for Russia to issue a rouble-denominated Eurobond.
"I doubt very much that we need such an instrument (rouble Eurobond) in the Eurobond market," Dubinin said in an interview with Reuters Financial Television.

"(There are) domestic rouble instruments, GKOs and OFZ bonds, and non-resident foreign investors participate intensly in this market. It concerns inflows and outflows of capital, and I prefer to keep the rouble market in Moscow, not in the Euromarket," he said.
In March, then finance minister Alexander Livshits said Russia could issue a rouble Eurobond in 1998.
Russia's rouble-denominated government securities have attracted strong foreign interest since the market was opened to non-residents last year.
Interest has been boosted by the stability of the rouble, which depreciates gently in a currency band known as a sloping corridor, similar to a crawling peg system.
Russia entered the Eurobond market last November with a $1.0 billion five-year bond. This year, it raised 2.0 billion mark with a seven-year deal.
Russian officials have said it would launch another two bonds this year raising at least $2.0 billion. One would be denominated in dollars.
